												I know what you're thinking, "He just doesn't like it because it requires you to use your brain! All he wants to do is play COD all day!" Now let me tell you two things. One: I dont hate this game, and two: I really don't like COD. This game is beautiful in its graphics and is very appealing to the eye, its just that once you get into the actual gameplay, it is very slow and almost doesn't progress in difficulty or controls at all. "Its meant to be a simple game! Its a thinking game!" I completely understand that aspect, it's just that while The Bridge tells you to do its excellently designed puzzles, it does nothing to keep you wanting to do the next thing, the storyline is little to nothing and the game starts off with you as an old man trying to climb up a hill which is the most boring intro experiences ever. "Its called minimalism!" I hear you say. I get that completely but while it accomplishes that goal it gives you nothing to hold on to, nothing to make you want to come back for more. I am going to say I dont recommend this game but I am more so in the middle of yes or no, which Steam unfortunately doesn't give you an option to put.I give it an overall 5/10.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 16, 2014
												I have a love-hate relationship with most platformer titles simply due to timed trials and ridiculous boss battles.  The Bridge thankfully avoids these pitfalls and offers a genuine puzzle-platformer experience.  The gameplay involves rotating the screen while simultaneously moving the character towards their goal--an unlocked door.  Sound easy?  Well it is...at first.  This is one of the most challenging puzzle games I've ever touched.  Any frustration generated fades away instantly as the solution aligns and warm satisfaction carries the player to the next level.  While Braid was interesting and fresh, it became unnecessarily complicated in an effort to scale with the player's progression.  On the other hand, The Bridge is an exercise in perspective rather than a gauntlet of reflex-based challenges and quite simply a joy to play.The Good:- eerie sound design that never becomes excessive- surreal art style that feels like the offspring of M.C. Escher with Edward Gorey's eyes- difficult puzzles (when I say puzzles, I mean actual puzzles not reflex challenges) that merely frustrate rather than enrage- time reversal element similar to Braid that allows for quick adjustments instead of forcing a complete restart- rudimentary story that allows the player to draw their own conclusions and never gets in the wayThe Bad: - engine can be sluggish at times (recent patches have improved this somewhat)- clunky installation (I have yet to uninstall, so this may have improved since launch)The Ugly:- honestly, nothing; one of the rare games that shines just enough not to create an unpleasant glare

number of helpful: 4 of 9 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 26, 2014
												The Bridge is by no means an incompetent game. It's a puzzler, with a quirky but pleasing art style, plenty of content, and an appropriately large level of difficulty. I might even have recommended it a few years ago. But I've since been spoiled by puzzlers of tremendous quality, like Braid, Fez, Portal, and (more controversially) The Misadventures of P.B. Winterbottom.In each of the above, the puzzles are soluble only with some kind of bright spark of an idea, with a relatively simple execution. In The Bridge, the puzzles often come down to trial and error, until eventually you arrive at a relatively complex execution. So, instead of a cathartic flash of inspiration at the end of a puzzle, instead you get a mild feeling of relief as the gauntlet is over.Perhaps if The Bridge had a more engaging style, like the above puzzlers do, its more grinding puzzles would not hold it back so. As it stands, The Bridge shoots for atmospheric, which it achieves to a limited extent. However, the atmosphere is too thin and too monotonous to really persuade me to come back to it. In the end, very little motivates me to actually play the game.If it's on sale, you might as well pick it up. Like I said, it's not an incompetent game. But, it's not worth full price, in my opinion.

content:
Posted: October 16, 2014
												The Bridge is a puzzle game that takes place in a series of level that seems to be inspired by the drawings of impossible constructions by M. C. Escher. The game uses two main mechanisms that the player can use to progress in each level - walking and the ability to turn the worlds around. There's a series of submechanisms depending on the level as well, including gravity manipulation, inversions and more.It's divided into 8 chapters (2 times 4) and as in most games the difficulty increases from each chapter. The first 4 chapter is in the "standard world" and the last 4 is in a mirrored world. The first 4 are challenging, but can be overcome with some thought, but the last 4 chapters are very, very difficult. Generally, though, each puzzle is well thought through and even levels using the same mechanisms are very different in design and the way they should be solved.While the gameplay is nice what's the most impressive about this game is its aesthetic side - the music is great and the art style of the game is absolutely spectacular. Overall, if you're into puzzles you're in for a treat. It's visually stunning and there's different challenges for everyone, although later levels are very difficult.EDIT 2 months later: I've reread the review, and while I still recommend it there should be a few notes added. It's a short game and I would not recommend picking it up for the standard €10 it goes for, but it is often for sale at around €2, which is a pretty reasonable price for a handful of hours worth of entertainment.Also it should be mentioned that this is not an easy puzzle game. The earliest chapters are fairly straightforward, but some of the later ones are ridiculously challenging and I admit that I had to check out YouTube for a few of them in order to even make sure what I was supposed to do.That said, if you can get it for a good price, there's still a few hours of good and entertaining exercise for the brain, but don't be supposed to find yourself a little frustrated with the later levels.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												"The Bridge" is right on the borderline of a good/bad game.  It's advertised as a strategy (puzzle) game and that's what it is (no problems there).  All the puzzles are interesting and involve walking through an environment, rotating that environment, and inverting yourself.  In general, each "level" consists of multiple "stages."  The early stages in each level tend to be easy and the final ones tend to be hard.  Again, no problem.  What I have issue with is that several of the puzzles hide the mechanism for solving it instead of just making the solution more complex.  Specifically, there are broken edges to the world that in almost every case, you can't walk/rotate around.  But, in a couple of puzzles, you can (and must).  There's also a problem with the velocity of the transit.  And then, there's the final Steam Achievement:  Collector.  It's pure gamification.  There's not a chance in the world that anyone could ever find more than one of these naturally.  The only way to find them is to do a search online.  Because of this unnecessary frustration, I was "this close" to rating the game down.  But, I did get several hours of thought out of the game.  So, I'm sticking with a Thumbs Up.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 23, 2015
												As someone who rather likes puzzles, I was surprised to find myself utterly bored by this game.  The mechanics revolve around rotating the world and manipulating gravity, and while you might think that would make for some interesting logic puzzles, it just ends up being incredibly sluggish and grey.  You play through four chapters of decent but unremarkable puzzles, then you go into a mirrored world of pretty much the same four chapters but with additional complications.  I stopped playing soon after getting into the mirrored world because the game just felt more like homework than entertainment.  If you're looking for a good puzzle game, this isn't it.  Try Portal, Limbo, Braid, Antichamber, or The Talos Principle.Edit:Alright, I went back and finished the game.  The puzzles get more interesting towards the end, but also more finicky.  Some require  you being very patient and precise as you carefully slide things around.  Some require you to lodge yourself against the edge of a button so you can slide other things around.  Some require you to to swing balls back and forth to try to get enough momentum.  Basically, you feel like you're fighting against the game mechanics instead of using them.  The experience is just not joyful the way better puzzle games are.

content:
Posted: June 19, 2014
												Beautiful puzzle game with simple mechanics that allow for very interesting levels. Heavily inspired by the art of M.C. Escher it takes you into a world where up and down can be turned into it's heads.Each level has a door that you have to reach and in some cases open with the help of some keys. There are elements that you have to avoid in some cases but you can use for your advantage in other levels. Generally, it does not require too much coordination to make things happen in real time and you can go at your own pace playing with the level until you find the right path. You could find a longer path but the game does not punishes for that. You complete each level or don't, there are no stars or differences for finding a solution quickly or with less effort,Very recommended.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 15, 2015
												Great artstyle, sketchy puzzles.  I really dig the penciled, black and white art direction of The Bridge, but the puzzles will make you feel more frustrated than smart.  It takes some obvious cues from games like Braid and reminds me of Monument Valley, but the easy to understand, reasonable difficulty curve of those titles are lost on The Bridge.  You move your avatar around and tilt the game world left or right while collecting keys and avoiding falling off the map or getting hit by a death ball.  The simple concept should lend itself to clean, heady puzzles, but fails as much as it succeeds.  The line art ends up getting in the way: it can be near impossible to tell what plane your character is standing or will end up while moving.  Many of the puzzles are also physics based and it's quite easy to screw something up by (reasonably) not thinking you should be finagaling the touchy objects as much as you have to.  This leads to frustrating solutions you'll most likely solve by endless tinkering and guesswork rather than looking at a level and feeling smart by reasoning it out.

content:
Posted: December 22, 2013
												This game is absolutely awsome! I thought a long time before I bought it and it was (and is) worth every penny. There is not so much of a story in the game so you shouldn't buy it because of a great mystery story or something like that. The artwork however is great and the riddles are clever, challenging and never unfair. You can try a dozen times and if you make a mistake you can rewind (like in prince of persia sot) and try something other. Mostly you can solve the riddles with pure logic - sometimes you will try and error over and over. The game still does not get boring because each riddle is another challenge with other problems. What I really like about the game is that at the firs minute you think "Oh, that is ginna be easy" just to be proven wrong a minute later. The first thing you have to do in each riddle is to figure out the mechanics (like in myst) only then you will have the chance to solve the riddle. It is so much fun and there are so many riddles (I'm still not through with the game after many hours of gameplay) and even the steam challenges are real challenges and (with one exception) solvable with some thinking. You will also fall in love with the beautifully handrawn black and white artwork and the minimalistic but fitting soundtrack. Buy the game if you like riddle games that really are challenging and really give you satisfaction after solving a riddle. The pure "Let's Play" hits on youtube should be proof enough that this game absolutely is worth it!

content:
Posted: November 11, 2013
												The Bridge is a puzzle game with an interesting twist and great art style but is it a game you want to spend your time with ? In The Bridge you play as a man with no name. He is stuck in a world so the only way to get out of it is to cross the bridge, but before doing that he must activate all 4 relics before crossing the bridge. So hows the game ? The game is an amazing piece of work that must be played by everyone who love a great game. The gameplay consist of puzzles where you have to get to a door and leave to the next area. The puzzles get seemingly difficult almost like impossible until at one time you have the I got it moment. This game also adds things like vortexes to suck you in to make it more difficult. But theres a trusty rewind option so you can go back in time to the moment where you think you made your mistake. Overall this game is amazing and you need to play it no matter what i give The Bridge a perfect score a 10/10

content:
Posted: September 7, 2014
												Sorry, I usually complete a game or at least spend a decent amount of hours in it, but I cannot, just for this game, progress anymore. I just don't have the motivation to play the game anymore. It's painful.So heres my review for this game:Initially The Bridge might look interesting. The game definitely has that 'indie' vibe you get from games like FTL. However everything will eventually, and quickly become boring, painful sometimes. You're going to reach the point where getting the achievements is your only motivation. But for me, I couldn't care less about that anymore.Since its an indie-game there are little mechanics. The basic being 'moving time backwards' and 'rotating the area so the orientation of gravity changes'. However you don't really have full control of the rotation due to the limit of puzzles. So none of that creating looking stuff in Portal. The game tries to be fancy by adding annoying obstacles like the 'void', but after a level or two a new toy replaces it. It's like having your gum taken away before you could finish chewing all the taste out of it. In addition, the visuals are misleading. Am I talking about the inaccessible stairs or the obvious routes you are limited to? No. See the rain (gravity) they add in stage 3.There's so little development, all those kewl new obstacles becomes repetitive quickly. This dude is just normal. Boringly normal. Song is boring. Literally the same stuff from stage 1 to the end.The game feels more like a chore than an interactive piece of art. I literally cannot lower my standard anymore without trying to wake myself up from bordom.But♥♥♥♥♥♥it was just 99 cents.

content:
Posted: February 14, 2015
												There are some cool things about this game, and maybe I'll peck away at it later, but on balance I'm more aggravated than appreciative of the game.What I like: The crazy art; the wild idea of bringing Escher to life; the mental gymnastics that go into solving everything; the instant rewind button so you don't have to start over every ten seconds; the interesting achievements.What I hate: The insanely long loading times every screen; difficulty isn't linear at all, which is fine but you can't skip a particularly feindish level and come back to it; you walk WAY too slow; some levels are dumb timing challenges where you're trying to get there fast enough and hit the button just at the right split-second, instead of an elegant solution falling into place.Too often that means rewinding constantly just to keep trying to hit the right button at the exact right time.

												I feel like I can't quite recommend this game and will try to sum up why without going on for too long.This game has recieved a ton of praise and much of it I agree with too. The art is gorgeous. The story is interesting, if a bit whimsical. I couldn't bring myself to play through the mirrored levels so perhaps the story gets more fleshed out later on. If you get the game for cheap you might just appreciate the art enough to find it worth the price anyway. I guess I kind of do. I've played through much worse games because I enjoyed an aspect of it like the music.My biggest gripes with the Bridge comes down to basically two things. The controls are kind of clumsy, and everything is SO SLOW. It's hard to be precise, and many of the puzzles requires a fair bit of precision. I very much enjoy even very hard platformers or puzzle games, when the controls are tight and you feel fully, 100% in control of what's going on. Luckily you can rewind time in this game to try again, but it takes away some of the joy when you want to do one thing and the game disagrees. It's hard to anticipate in advance what might happen when you do one thing in the more physics-heavy puzzles, which lead me to my next point. Rewinding time is slow and takes you out of the game. Restarting a puzzle takes a bunch of time as well as I had to get into the menus every time. Your character walks super slow. Gravity is low, so it takes time for things to fall in place and you to see the actions of your thoughts. New mechanics are introduced at times but are generally poorly explained. I enjoy finding out about things on my own! But not when it involves new controls that you only find out about through random button mashing or looking at the game controls again (for an action I didn't know how/where to perform it!). I was stuck on one of the simpler puzzles halfway into the game and had to resort to a youtube video only to proclaim "how was I supposed to know I could do that!"Perhaps I was hoping for more of a pure puzzle game rather than platformer. As it is I felt I spent too much time battling the intricacies of the game and tons of trial and error rather than thinking about how to approach things logically and figure out things in my head.I have no doubt many people enjoy the game, but these are my thoughts and someone may find them interesting or to be an influence in whether the game is worth a try.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 18
												The Bridge is a little gem that may have escaped some in the past, though its inclusion in multiple bundles has exposed it to a wide variety of people. It even has a release on consoles now. And it deserves it. Though a little short, the art style is perfectly encapsulated within the gameplay and story, with an eerie and solemn vibe matched by a wonderful classical score. You can tell they ripped straight from M.C. Escher, but then again why not? It's beautiful.Once you are finished with the main game they have a mirror mode to try as well. A lot of people got this for basically nothing, so it's hard to argue about price. The game is definitely worth 5 or ten dollars alone. Very solid gameplay, and a few puzzles that will definitely warp your mind. There are also a few secrets to find throughout that should keep anyone wanting more busy. Nothing bad to say about this one. Solid design, visuals, and a really nice soundtrack.

number of helpful: 16 of 35 people (46%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 29, 2014
												Despite the fact that a character can be controlled, it's not a platformer. There is no jump button and the character moves like a snail. So it's all about the puzzles, primarily based on turning the screen to change the center of gravity. And... it is quite boring and the mechanics become so intricate it becomes a chore to solve the level. It feels so tedious that I quit half-way, when I noticed that the next chapters were the same as before, but mirrored.The mechanics to spice things up are a big stone ball that kills the player but is needed to press buttons, a vortex to suck up anything that gets close, portals that make the player change color to interact with different parts of the level in a specific order of events, and veils to modify the... well it has never been very clear to me what they do. There isn't even a key to reset the current level, the player has to do it from the menu. Lastly, the story isn't compelling.There are clear inspirations from Braid, but it is not an experience near as enjoyable or interesting.So I don't end on a completely negative review, I liked the art and some of the musics.

number of helpful: 7 of 17 people (41%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 25, 2014
												(Experience: completed roughly 10 rounds)(Time spent: around 20min)(Bought price: $0.99 at 90% discount)     This is definitely an interesting screen-rotating game that you rarely see as a casual open-minded gamer.  However, after completing the first chapter (roughly 6-7 challenges) I got completely bored of the instant repetitive nature of the gameplay. As you progress, The Bridge introduces a number of new elements of challenges - for example, a wrecking ball that kills you upon touch - but even these little details will not grab hold of the gamer's attention long enough to realise that the experiences you get out of your progression is not much different from your first 10 minutes of playing.     Bottomline: it's a nice experience but it's not worth more than a dollar's worth of your time. Also, you will be looking at a lot of grey. A whole lot of grey the entire time you play.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 7, 2014
												Sorry, I usually complete a game or at least spend a decent amount of hours in it, but I cannot, just for this game, progress anymore. I just don't have the motivation to play the game anymore. It's painful.So heres my review for this game:Initially The Bridge might look interesting. The game definitely has that 'indie' vibe you get from games like FTL. However everything will eventually, and quickly become boring, painful sometimes. You're going to reach the point where getting the achievements is your only motivation. But for me, I couldn't care less about that anymore.Since its an indie-game there are little mechanics. The basic being 'moving time backwards' and 'rotating the area so the orientation of gravity changes'. However you don't really have full control of the rotation due to the limit of puzzles. So none of that creating looking stuff in Portal. The game tries to be fancy by adding annoying obstacles like the 'void', but after a level or two a new toy replaces it. It's like having your gum taken away before you could finish chewing all the taste out of it. In addition, the visuals are misleading. Am I talking about the inaccessible stairs or the obvious routes you are limited to? No. See the rain (gravity) they add in stage 3.There's so little development, all those kewl new obstacles becomes repetitive quickly. This dude is just normal. Boringly normal. Song is boring. Literally the same stuff from stage 1 to the end.The game feels more like a chore than an interactive piece of art. I literally cannot lower my standard anymore without trying to wake myself up from bordom.But♥♥♥♥♥♥it was just 99 cents.

												This is an OK game. But nothing more. While the mechanics are simple and easy to get your head around, they're far too simple. The game lacks any complexity that really draws you in - and the lack of any real failure state is frustrating. It just doesn't do very much for me.

												Do you want a puzzle game that is more confusing and pretentious than Braid without any of the charm or nostalgia? content:
Posted: August 18, 2013
												The game is a puzzle platforming (ish, you walk around) with a mix of annoyance and headache. You walk around, manipulating the gravity of the world, avoiding balls of death and collecting keys. Much like braid the complexity of the puzzles increase each level and there is often a new mechanic introduced.I would say that Either you love or hate this game, its very well done, but I am personally not the correct player for this type of game so I didnt like it very much after the first 3 chapters (each chapter is 7 levels).I kind of lost interest after a while to solve the levels, so I started looking at solutions on youtube for the final 2 levels and the mirror world levels, just so I could take the achievements. All in all I played 4.2 hours, but if you solve everything yourself then I wouldnt be surprised if it will take about 7-8 hours or more.Graphics is as they look like in the screenshots and trailers, personally i both like and dislike them, but they work fine for the purpose.Technically the game worked fine, no crashes or anything, though it seems to run quite heavy, I couldnt play youtube movies in the steam overlay without them lagging.I would suggest buying Braid instead of this, better graphics, better music and better gameplay. Much less frustrating and more engaging story.If youve already played Braid and want something more thinking-heavy, then you should get this. Beware of annoying deaths though.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												Combines the puzzles of Braid with the artwork (and story, to some degree) of Limbo. The puzzles here are really tough and the learning curve is steep. There's a good reason for this though - once you've worked out the puzzle, that's it, it's over. It needs to be difficult to be playable at all. Which is a shame, because a game that's too hard takes away the fun of playing it. I don't feel like there's enough novelty of what you can do in this game as far as input goes - most of the game is either played in your head or trial and error. Both Braid and Limbo are better games because of this.

number of helpful: 5 of 14 people (36%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 11, 2013
												I really would have wished for a more neutral rating, since the first levels really are awesome. I played the first 3 chapters and enjoyed them immensely. The riddles make sense and are pure logic.But with chapter 4 they introduce a new element that just does not get explained and suddenly it's just try and error. There is no help in the game that explains how elements are working. And then there are bugs - I got stuck at a level in Chapter 4, so stopped playing to continue the next day. But instead of loading the correct level it was loading an already completed level. And then it jumped the one I failed previously. Given how long the title is on the market a bug they could have addressed by now.So if you like logic riddles the first 3 chapters are among the nicest I have played in a long time. But if you find it frustrating when games go from logic to trial and error you might not want to buy this.

content:
Posted: February 9, 2015
												I have a soft spot for certain titles, games that force me to change my perspective on what makes a "decent game". In this modern era, most folks flock in droves mindlessly to the next huge broseph game, super sharp graphics with a simple theme using the same old formula. *Yawn* Then games like this one come along, and deserves nothing but praise, but alas, becasue of a general lack of mainstream promotions remain a "gem" in the gravel mostly passed by those who cannot think for themselves and are unable to choose what is a great game via hype trains. This was a pleasure and a joy so far. It challenges people to use a tool mostly ignored in modern gaming. A brain. (Sick burn dude) With challenging puzzles, amazing themes and mechanics, and a beautiful art style, it was a pleasure. When a puzzle is moments from being solved, and you strike that "AH-HA!" point, it feels so satisfying. Nothing but props for this title. Well made and whimsical, it is something i would recommend for everyone and anyone who is willing to challenge themselves. Achievements and Badge progress for fellow farmers and a atmosphere that can stand the test of time. Amazing all around. Just avoid those google sites, and really wrap your skills around a void blanket called "The Bridge"

												If you’ve played any indie platformers then you’ve already played this game. It’s your typical puzzle platformer game but with a twist, and in this case the twist is the frustratingly slow ability to change the direction of gravity. number of helpful: 1 of 6 people (17%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 22, 2014
												Summary: Gravity based puzzle game with time reversal mechanic.Positives: Escher style pencil art is fantastic. Atmosphere is well done. No puzzle requires skill only thought (although some practice required). Relatively short game, entirely complete in a few hours. Time reversal serves to recover errors and refine movement quickly.Negatives: Doesn't play with optical illusions despite art style. While it feels very similar to Braid in style and utilises the same time reversal function, there is no contest on which is the better game. Time reversal not really explored beyond recovery of errors, bar one secret.Conclusion: If you've not played Braid or are not intending to then this is an enjoyable puzzle game to add to your collection. Well contained this will not however have much replayability, good or bad depending what you are looking for. If you have Braid or were thinking about playing Braid, then this game from a puzzle perspective is the quite the inferior challenge and experience.

content:
Posted: September 29, 2014
												You know when you're browsing a site like Reddit or StumbleUpon, and you see that one post that's really bizzare and doesn't really make sense unless you examine it for a few minutes? But the moment everything falls into place you have that "aaaaaaaaaaah that was really cool" moment and then go about your day, never to remember that moment or post ever again?This is the game version of that senario. This game is so short I beat it within the short timespan between waking up at 8 in the morning before leaving for class at 10. During that time the game held my attention irrevocably, making my mind and perception twist and warp until it was able to wrap around the rules of the particular level that I was on. But the moment all the pieces fell into place, the puzzle was solved immediately and I went about to the next level, ready to meld my mind around the next challenge. Then I completely forgot I owned this game after that.Conclusion:4/10Interesting puzzles, but very underwhelming once you were able to change your perspective. If you want to try for yourself, then I suggesst waiting for around for a 50-75% sale.

content:
Posted: October 5, 2014
												Not a bad game by any stretch of the imagination, but it seems like it very much wants to be Braid, and it's simply not good of a game, in either gameplay or experience.  The game's biggest weakeness is that the normal game is too simple, but what seems like the "real" game, the mirror levels, is far too difficult.  The normal games puzzles are fairly easy to figure out without too much difficult, but rarely feel as rewarding as a great puzzle game often does when solving a particularly good one.  The mirror levels introduce such a level of execution difficulty that even when the solution is known, the execution level required makes the game very difficult.  Not a good endorsement of a puzzle game, in my mind.  In the end, despite completing all the normal levels and multiple mirror levels, I simply can't say this game gave me the puzzles or the satisfaction I was looking for, even when it was challenging.  Some great art and ideas, but the execution is lacking, and the cohesive whole is good, but never great.  If you love puzzle games, pick this up on sale, and you'll find some good there...but if you're on the fence, make sure you don't expect this to be another Braid, and go in with your expectation set accordingly.

number of helpful: 1 of 7 people (14%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 21, 2014
												A real brainmelter. A tough one, but fun. Swirls, reversed gravity, alternate dimensions... It's a tough puzzler. Add the fact that you can turn the world clockwise and counter-clockwise, and that you meet clones of yours (which can't collide or it's game over) and it simply can get really messy. I had a hard time with this game. Dimension changing and rotating make this game complex and requires a lot of tries and patience.Another thing you have to take into account is timing, which is sometimes the most important thing which you simply can't avoid.It's not a puzzler for everyone. Some people will find it annoying and confusing for many reasons. The graphical style also doesn't make anything easier. Even though maps look fantastic, black/white/shades of grey colours sometimes play with your mind and you don't know what's going on. This game would be a perfect for me to ragequit and throw buckets of crap at the developer, but they would not let me do this. This game has a feature every indie game should have (especially puzzlers and platformers) - REWIND. Yes, you can rewind your actions. You can rewind infinitely during a level and even as far as to the very beginning. I have to admit I did not enjoy all the levels. I just found some to be too crazy and confusing. ??? What's going on here and how do I solve it. I asked myself these question quite a few times. I suggest trying to beat them, but even if you get stuck like I did, use a guide. I used a guide quite a few times as my brain reached its limits and so did the patience, but I wanted to experience the game and at least try to beat them.This a confusing game, which requires a lot of patience, attempts and thinking, but thankfully rewind feature saves the day. Get if you like weird setting and brain challenges.

number of helpful: 0 of 5 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												Not worth the time or money, really. I only finished the game out to completion because I'm that way. Sometimes it's simply because I spent the money and other times it is because of my OCD. There are games that I have just dropped completely, however, but this wasn't one of them.The Bridge had a very interesting idea, but it was poorly executed. Braid was a MUCH better game that you should go purchase right now and not waste your money on this cheap "sequel."For me, the puzzles just got too annoying too quickly and required too much painstaking effort to make sure the littlest piece didn't mess up. As OCD as I am, I usually enjoy immense effort in things like that, but this game just rubbed me the wrong way.The gameplay was also very slow. Even if you know what to do in a level, it takes forever to get it done. The walking and turning is just terribly slow in something like 95% of the levels. Some people argue that it's because it is level-dependent, but there were only like 2 levels where I noticed the pacing was increased vastly. Other than that, all of them seemed the same slow drag to me.Besides that, the color palette and lack of a story made it boring. Braid told a story and looked beautiful doing it. I usually don't hold games up side-by-side in a review, but this game tried to repeat Braid's success and failed. The game would have looked much better styled up like Braid (and it even shows that in two different 5 second scenes) and it really needed a story.Overall, it seemed like a boring slog through annoying puzzles that led to no real payout of any kind.

content:
Posted: November 17, 2013
												The Bridge is a 2D logic puzzle game that forces the player to reevaluate their preconceptions of physics and perspective. It is Isaac Newton meets M. C. Escher. Manipulate gravity to redefine the ceiling as the floor while venturing through impossible architectures. Explore increasingly difficult worlds, each uniquely detailed and designed to leave the player with a pronounced sense of intellectual accomplishment. The Bridge exemplifies games as an art form, with beautifully hand-drawn art in the style of a black-and-white lithograph.

Posted: June 27, 2014
												This was my go-to puzzle game when I needed to kill time. It layers each of its mechanics slowly, and, before you know it, you’re stumped in a puzzle where gravity is sideways, alternate gravity is upside-down, the map screen is tilted at a 45-degree angle, and the Newton-wannabe that you control is falling off of the platform.  Luckily, when you die, you can rewind time in a very Braid-like manner to re-attempt the puzzle. The game is built on the ability to rotate the screen, changing the gravity for the protagonist and allowing him to access otherwise unreachable destinations. In each puzzle, you must get a key and go through a door. This simple goal becomes complicated when the Escher-inspired puzzles begin rotating.  As you explore more puzzles, other features are introduced: a white plane and a black plane, the ability to change or align these planes’ gravity, and a portal that flips the 2D puzzle entirely.I find the black-and-white art beautiful, but it’s distracting or obscuring in some puzzles. The story also takes a note from Braid: minor bits after a few puzzles, fed to you with a vague, heavy hand. I’m not sure where the Faux Newton plot is going, but I don’t care. As long as you don’t take the game as seriously as it wants you take it, it’s enjoyable.

Posted: July 10, 2014
												This game had me within the first 10 seconds. It is beautifully drawn and boasts a unique style of gameplay. A definite must for Escher fans. The nature of the puzzles takes some time to get used to and the first half of the game isn't too difficult. In saying that, I spent a good deal of my hours played on the last half of the game, when the puzzles proved a lot more difficult. This game is a workout for the brain. Not much going on control wise.... walk left, walk right, tilt left, tilt right. It's just when to do what and how much of it to do that really matters in this game. Too much tilt and you can find yourself falling straight off the map. I found this game challenging enough. Each puzzle could be solved within a reasonable amount of time and it did not make me want to throw my computer out the window....which is always a good thing. Combine the puzzles with the artwork and gameplay and you have yourself a very enjoyable game. I recommend it to anyone who likes puzzle games and give it a 9 out of 10. Points lost because it just ended all too quickly for me. I wanted more!!!

Posted: January 25, 2014
												Enjoyable and short puzzle-platformer where the "gimmick" is the ability to rotate the entire level in order to manipulate the gravity of you and other objects around you. The rotation is similar to And Yet It Moves in that regard, and there's a simple time-rewind mechanic in order to undo your mistakes (although this does not actually factor into any of the actual puzzles for the most part). There's also an "overworld" that consists of your house, the yard around it, and multiple doors to the different, numbered worlds (and individual doors to each of the sub-levels in those worlds). So in those two regards (overworld layout and the simple "undo your mistakes" button), it somewhat reminds me of Braid. The art style is interesting, complete with odd geometry and floating objects, but the lack of color for the main game gets a bit tiring. The puzzles have a good difficulty curve, and getting all the achievements requires some work (and/or guides). It's not very long and feels like And Yet It Moves with touches of Braid, but the mechanics and difficulty are both solid. I'd buy it on sale for a few dollars.

Posted: August 29, 2014
												A genuinely good puzzler.  The controls are simple: A & D move you, left & right arrows spin the world, W triggers doors and inverters.  Some levels take careful planning, and even when you see how to solve the level, working out how to make it happen can be tricky as well!  6 rooms in each of 4 levels, and then the same mirrored; 48 levels in all.  I thought the mirrored levels would be simple, but while the room is a mirror of the original, there are other twists to add challenges to them as well.The game's artwork is again, simple, but genuinely good.  The levels are black & white, but animated in a similar manner as old cartoons; things like the shading of the doors changing from frame to frame, giving it a mild flicker.  It's delightfully charming and a nice touch.Overall, a highly recommended puzzler.

Posted: August 28, 2014
												Play Time: 52 minsLevels acheived: Chapter 4 level 4Opinion: Boring                I enjoy playing challenging puzzle games alot as it's nice to have my brian be the deciding factor on whether I win or lose and not the skill at using mouse and keyboard. So I bought this interesting game for just 70p to see what it's like. I was rather disappointed.                 The game delivers a nice looking world with each level that is fun to look at as the landscape is very confusing, using quirky optical illusions to distort the map. This I really liked but in the way of puzzle gameplay it was slow and not very challenging. I found I could complete most levels through just using trial and error once or twice to get to the end instead of actually using my brain to figure out where I was meant to go and how I was supposed to minipulate the terrain (yes this can be considered a fault on my part and I respect that). The one time I did use my brain to track my steps through the puzzle world was more like going through a maze than completing a puzzle, not a very puzzling level.                Another reason I don't recommend it is the progression through the levels is not at all rewarding. The story was not at all interesting if at all existent, and the reason I say this is because at the end of each level there was a thought for you to read. It did not tell a story or explained why this was happening, it was just nonsense. This coupled with the very uninteresting new components added each chapter, left me with no motivation to continue through the levels to discover what was at the end. It also didn't help that the character walks the pace of a snail, "If you would like to get there this life time that would be great."                 What I did like about the game was the ability to warp back in time when you failed, instead of completely restarting the game. Having to restart every time I died, keys flying off the map, boulders getting too up close and personal, would of been very irritating. The map design was very clever with all the optical illusions and the confusing layout, with the added art form the maps where nice to look at and very unique.                 The game is unique with map and puzzle design but not fun to play and gives no reason to continue playing.

Posted: August 28, 2014
												Play Time: 52 minsLevels acheived: Chapter 4 level 4Opinion: Boring                I enjoy playing challenging puzzle games alot as it's nice to have my brian be the deciding factor on whether I win or lose and not the skill at using mouse and keyboard. So I bought this interesting game for just 70p to see what it's like. I was rather disappointed.                 The game delivers a nice looking world with each level that is fun to look at as the landscape is very confusing, using quirky optical illusions to distort the map. This I really liked but in the way of puzzle gameplay it was slow and not very challenging. I found I could complete most levels through just using trial and error once or twice to get to the end instead of actually using my brain to figure out where I was meant to go and how I was supposed to minipulate the terrain (yes this can be considered a fault on my part and I respect that). The one time I did use my brain to track my steps through the puzzle world was more like going through a maze than completing a puzzle, not a very puzzling level.                Another reason I don't recommend it is the progression through the levels is not at all rewarding. The story was not at all interesting if at all existent, and the reason I say this is because at the end of each level there was a thought for you to read. It did not tell a story or explained why this was happening, it was just nonsense. This coupled with the very uninteresting new components added each chapter, left me with no motivation to continue through the levels to discover what was at the end. It also didn't help that the character walks the pace of a snail, "If you would like to get there this life time that would be great."                 What I did like about the game was the ability to warp back in time when you failed, instead of completely restarting the game. Having to restart every time I died, keys flying off the map, boulders getting too up close and personal, would of been very irritating. The map design was very clever with all the optical illusions and the confusing layout, with the added art form the maps where nice to look at and very unique.                 The game is unique with map and puzzle design but not fun to play and gives no reason to continue playing.

												This isn't so much a negative review as it is a "know what you're getting into" review. Technically a No, but with a giant asterisk. I bought this game on sale for a dollar. I definitely got my dollar's worth. I think that if I had paid full price, I would have been disappointed, but only because of the glowing 9/10 reviews. Had I expected less, I would've been more satisfied with what I got.First, the puzzles themselves weren't great. There was no sense of build as I went on. I never felt like I was learning more about what it meant to interact in a world of impossible shapes. I had no "Aha!" moments where a shift in my thinking made the solution obvious. More than a few times my reaction was "Really? It was that easy?" The later puzzles pile on complexity but feel more like a slog than an intricate problem.This is compounded by the second problem: The controls feel very clunky. It makes the exploratory / trial-and-error phase of learning about the puzzles more work than fun. It's not all bad. The art and sound design are excellent. There is some fun puzzling to be had. It's just overall the game fails to deliver. I give it 6 misspent youths out of a possible 10. If you go in expecting 9/10, you will be disappointed.

Posted: January 29, 2014
												The Bridge was quite a satisfying puzzle platformer with a fantastic art style. The premise is that you navigate a series of mathematical constructs based on the work of M C Escher. Each construct is a separate self contained puzzle where you must manipulate gravity by rotating the world and eventually reach the exit. Eschers drawings were already a marvel to try and navigate in a visual sense and placing them into a game such as this now enables you to actually explore them! The art style also matches this concept perfectly by closely replicating the original Escher drawings and does not distract from solving the puzzles.The puzzles themselves start off fairly simple and I was able to fly through the first three areas fairly quickly. Although, the difficulty really ramps up in the second half of the game. That being said solving the puzzles felt intuitive and I never had to resort to fast timing or twitch mechanics. That being said, once I had a handle of how all the gravity mechanics worked together the last few puzzles did not provide as much of a challenge as I was expecting. A few other features that I really appreciated were the ability to rewind time and the visual cues that were used to indicate how gravity applied to each different object on screen. The visual cues were especially useful late game when there were often multiple gravity effects in play at one time. Also, the ability to simply rewind time and undo mistakes encouraged experimentation and trial and error, which was perfect when I couldn't immediately see the solution to a puzzle. Although, I felt that sometimes I could just trial and error all the way to a solution without ever actually 'solving' it.All in all I did rather enjoy playing The Bridge, the puzzles were challenging for the most part while not becoming utterly frustrating. Not as inspired as the likes of Braid but there were definitely some interesting mechanics. Would recommend for sure.

Posted: August 26, 2014
												Score: 7/10If you want a long, fullfilling challenge I'll warn you: The Bridge is a relatively short puzzle game, unless you get stuck in a single place for long you should really be able to finish EVERYTHING in about five hours (Though you should find yourself a guide if you want the collector achievement, some are impossible to get without hints that, no, you won't find in game).About the game in itself: the graphics are quite nice and lovely, if you love Escher you'll LOVE the game just by staring at its impossible graphics which, at the same time, make for mind-boggling puzzles.Sadly, the mechanics of the game are NOT as complex as the graphics suggests...As most puzzles games, expecially those where you control the world as well as your character, your abilities are limited (This time more by speed than actual limiting, but if a death-ball is between you and where you want to go forget about changing the world fast enough that you "skip" the ball: it'll follow you to your death)This however makes the solution maybe too linear, sometimes making the user start to meta-think the solution (going left not because it'll lead me to the solution but because going right will kill me so it's obviously not the answer).Adding more mechanics doesn't fix it, as essentially starts becoming "Okay, can't go left, nor right, I'll use that switcher there then."The hardest levels try to fix this by relying more on momentum and timed movements, while they succeed I personally dislike those due to feeling "un-puzzle-like" to me.The puzzles tend to be still challenging if you try to "understand" the solution, expecially due to the peculiar graphics making it hard to get a clear idea of what's going on the screen, so I suggest everyone playing this game to do this, but it lost some points due to being too weak to the "trial-and-error" solution.

Posted: August 24, 2015
												In each level, you have to get to the exit door. You do this by walking, rotating gravity, avoiding evil balls, pick up keys, and control a bunch of other mechanics. Most levels are clever, but can be solved with some trial-and-error. Some require precise movement/timing/alignment of gravity. This can get very annoying, but at least you can rewind as much as you want. There is some Escher stuff going on in the level design; paths that cross themselves.This game will not appeal to everybody: it is very frustrating at times, especially when you want to get one of the balls to move in a certain direction but rotating gravity makes the dude slide to his death. If you want a slow, hand-drawn physics puzzle game and don't easily get dizzy, I can recommend this game, but only just. Worth playing, but not worth €9,99.

												8/10Difficult. I loved this game because, yes it was hard, but I enjoyed it. The game play is simple using A and D to move left and right in order to turn the environment around. The puzzles are engaging and you really feel a sigh of relief and a sense of achievement when you finsh this game. 												This is a wonderful puzzle game that fans of MC Escher, or the mobile game Monument Valley, should definitely look into. If you like perspective and logic puzzles this is not to be missed.The dreamy hand drawn and monochramic art style is full of great little details and the different level elements really come into prominence when you start rotating and using the stage. In one level I hadn't noticed that the 'log' on the ground was actually a lit candle when the stage was rotated 90 degrees and the candle was suddenly upright. Flourishes like how the character is sketched into each level, and the way a  'trace' of him is left each time you fail and rewind, lend a lot of personality to the game as well. It feels like an Escher drawing so it really does feel like we're in the playground of his imagination.I play puzzle games in small bursts but I can already tell that The Bridge is one of those special games where I will be eager to tackle and finish the puzzles and the game, but I'll also be hoping that the game won't end any time soon. Great  stuff. A+

Posted: December 31, 2013
												This game feels to me like it's trying to be Braid 2, with esoteric rhetoric, simple-yet-convoluted symbolism, and pensive vibes (not to mention a rewind mechanic). Unfortunately, for me it just falls flat. What made Braid really work for me was how well-executed the rewind mechanic was, how versatile it was, and how everything built off of time to create a unique and thoughtful atmosphere, rather than a bunch of random puzzles thrown together. The controls were tight, the artwork beautiful, and the puzzles complex enough to keep me thinking about them and coming back to them for days.I can't really say the same applies here. While the mathematician-style of abstract thought and thinking in several dimensions is present here, the game comes across as something simple trying to be something pensive. The controls are slow. Your character moves the speed of a snail in molasses frozen in an iceburg buried under a mountain. While this does aid in the pensive vibes I get from this game, nothing about this game is all that pensive (and I was feeling this even BEFORE I played Antichamber, which succeeds dramatically where this game does not). The puzzles are extremely simple, at least for the first three chapters, and everything can be done with minimal experimentation. I would really like it if i could think about the puzzles at my own pace, rather than solving a puzzle mentally in seconds and having to slow my mind down to a crawl as the character ever so slowly meanders across the screen. Antichamber and Braid do this brilliantly; you can move around and come back at any time if a particular puzzle looks too hard, and solve it in seconds if you finally figure out how. Here, there's no such joy of discovery, since you'll likely discover the solution on accident as you wander ever so slowly back and forth.Unfortunately, this game also suffers from what a lot of indie games seem to nowadays: a terrible difficulty spike for no reason. The first three chapters (and half the fourth) were unbelivably simple and required no thoughtwork whatsoever. Then, one level abruptly is insaely complex, time-consuming, and far more difficult than anything before it, with nothing leading up to it at all. That's not how you design a puzzle game. That's not how you design any game.Lastly, new mechanics aren't introduced well. It's totally fine to have new mechanics as a game progresses, but it took me quite a few minutes to realize that those arrows flip gravity. Why? Because the flipping-gravity effect looks nothing like it has anything to do with flipping gravity. I would expect something straightforward; rotate the camera 180 degrees, grey out the screen a bit, maybe flash a two-way arrow, something simple. Instead, there's a circle wipe from the center outwards reminiscent of a Powerpoint slideshow, and the level kinda looks like it's changed in the process, but I can't really tell because the level is vertically symmetrical anyway. Oops. Oh, and gently touching one of those boulders kills you dead on the spot, because why not.It's stuff like this that just irks me about a game. Especially because, just with a few more months of beta-testing and polish, this game could be absolutely amazing. They've got some fantastic ideas here, and they've executed them horribly. That's just the saddest thing for me, because I like games that are great, and this one just barely isn't there.

Posted: August 16, 2015
												I guess this game was heavily inspired by Bastion. But that one at least was fun.Graphics style is good.Music is basically missing and the few chords get annoying soon.The first three worlds are way too simple.The fourth world gets interesting and challenging, but it never explains the gravity changing principles properly, you're likely to search for help online.The last level and the following "mirrored worlds" are based on ugly gimmicks, like pixel positioning. Many parts of that are no longer a puzzle game, but something like a reverse platformer (try to hit that ledge with that ball by controlling gravity).You never know what you can step on (and from which angle) and what is just decoration.The loading times are terrible.But worst of all, the whole game is unbelievably slow. All animations take eternity, the gravity rotation is very slow, the game time can't be sped up, and reversing time is tiringly slow as well (if you spent 2 minutes without movement just pondering about the level and then want to return past that point, you're going to spend a lot of time looking at a still character). The whole game is so lazy, that it took me all my will to continue with more levels in the mirrored worlds. It's just wasting your time instead of letting you play. And all of that could be solved so easily - let people skip initial level animations, and add a button to speed up game time. But it isn't.

												A nice little puzzle game with a steep learning curve. Pros: I personally liked the art style, which I think worked well with puzzles that remind me of optical illusions. The rewind mechanic is one of the more forgiving aspects of this game, similar to the Prince of Persia's dagger, but without a time limit. The puzzles were engaging enough that I remained invested in playing through to the finish.Cons: Puzzles range from really simple to extremely difficult. I didn't mind using video walkthroughs for some of them, but while some puzzles were easy enough once you figured out the trick, others I wouldn't have figured out without the walkthrough (i.e. using momentum).Bottom line: I would recommend playing through it once, but for me it doesn't hold a lot of replay value.

Posted: June 20, 2015
												8/10Difficult. I loved this game because, yes it was hard, but I enjoyed it. The game play is simple using A and D to move left and right in order to turn the environment around. The puzzles are engaging and you really feel a sigh of relief and a sense of achievement when you finsh this game. The achievements set up a good challenge as some are really hard to get which adds a little extra to the game. There are a lot of puzzles in this game there are 8 main chapters and 9 sub-chapters per chapter (72 in total). There is a lot of replability in this game once you have forgoten the puzzle's solutions.I liked the black and white asthetic style. It suits the game and is fitting for the story.If you pay enough attention to the environment you can tell that there is a story behind all the things that you are doing. I did not feel as though the story was forced on me though so if you just want a puzzle game that is what you will get.Overall I enjoyed this game and found the puzzles a real challenge. I am ashamed to say it, but I had to look at a walkthrough for a couple of puzzles because I just could not work them out. If you are like me and you love stories there is a subtle one running throughout, but as I say it can by just a puzzle game.

Posted: June 20, 2015
												This is a wonderful puzzle game that fans of MC Escher, or the mobile game Monument Valley, should definitely look into. If you like perspective and logic puzzles this is not to be missed.The dreamy hand drawn and monochramic art style is full of great little details and the different level elements really come into prominence when you start rotating and using the stage. In one level I hadn't noticed that the 'log' on the ground was actually a lit candle when the stage was rotated 90 degrees and the candle was suddenly upright. Flourishes like how the character is sketched into each level, and the way a  'trace' of him is left each time you fail and rewind, lend a lot of personality to the game as well. It feels like an Escher drawing so it really does feel like we're in the playground of his imagination.I play puzzle games in small bursts but I can already tell that The Bridge is one of those special games where I will be eager to tackle and finish the puzzles and the game, but I'll also be hoping that the game won't end any time soon. Great  stuff. A+

Posted: January 28, 2014
												June 4, 2015The Bridge is an interesting game. The pacing is nice in the first half, but slows down later. Some players may find the obscure storyline annoying, but the story is mostly in the background. There's a surprising amount of puzzle variation for only having 4 real buttons for controls. Keyboard controls fine, nothing requires analog controls.I'm not really sure what to think of the game after finishing it. The story is interesting but feels incomplete. The second half of the game gets a bit busy with too many objects to manipulate. New mechanics are added for only a few levels, and are not cleanly introduced.I like the game, but the later levels became a bit of a drag, to the point that I just needed walkthroughs as I didn't want to spend a lot of time with uncompelling puzzles. So it's good early, becomes a bit too precision-based in the very end. Not too frustrating, but I've had better puzzles. It's good, but not a rush-buy at full price. I'd recommend the game to puzzle fans for at least 50% off, under $5 USD.

Posted: January 31, 2015
												If you're looking for a game to engross you for hours on end, let me start by saying this is not for you. With 8.5 hours into the game, I have all but completed the whole thing. The whole story was completed within probably 6 hours, if you would consider it a story. It's more of just multiple puzzles put together to really twist your brain. With each puzzle being completed, the story get just a little bit more "interesting".The game does make you think; afterall it is a puzzler. You simply have to walk left and right or rotate the world left or right. With just those four directional queues, you have to maneuver your way through around 50 puzzles. If you make a mistake, you can rewind time as far back as you want or need to. It feel like an indepth platformer / puzzler. The visual appeal is there in a sense. The game doesn't project visually stunning graphics. It's meant to have a simple, trippy, and hand drawn / rustic feeling. It gits the mysterious category it is portraying. The layout of the puzzles is what causes the trippy atmosphere. All of the puzzles encompass physically impossible maps and puzzle boards. Sometimes while rotating the world and walking, my eyes would flutter and become dizzy just from trying to comprehend how what I am doing is working. I don't play many games. I tend to look at them, think I'd enjoy them and add them to my library. This one actually caught my attention in my library and ended up binge playing it thoroughly. Is it worth the $9.99? I don't think so. If you can get it for a dollar or two, maybe. There was also a flaw in the game where, if you free fall for a long period of time, the framerate drops immensly to 1 or 2 fps. Very unhappy about that. This is the exact reason I did not get 100% of the achievements. The game also supports full controller support. I opted to use the keyboard only as 1) I didn't even realize that it supported the controller until I was 3/4 done this review and 2) I wanted to try just keyboard control. I use a controller 9/10 when playing a game through Steam or on my PC and wanted to really get a feel for the KB/M controls of games.Overall, I'm happy I played the game. It was interesting and something a little off the beaten path, per se. Would I ever play it again? I don't think so. Maybe once or twice to show people or try to get 100% one last time, but that's about it. I definitely won't be back anytime soon as I doubt the framerate issue will be fixed anytime soon.

												The game uses a mechanic similar to And Yet It Moves, you twist the world around you to complete puzzles. Difficulty increases steadily, sometimes a little sharper than expected. The world gives you small environmental clues to help foster a solution.The only thing I will say is that the mirrored worlds are horse♥♥♥♥♥♥ They aren't mirrored, they are just more difficult versions of previous puzzles, often times needing a ridiculous amount of patience or finesse to pull off. Using physics that were never necessary before. It is no longer about solving the puzzle, all about abusing the game mechanic to get to your goal. It's the terrible half of the game.

Posted: January 25, 2015
												Short, sweet, and utterly wonderful to look at, this eyecatching game has a knack for capturing the cerebral art of M.C. Escher perfectly, but with a price in puzzle design. In concept, his mind bending art is perfect for creating interesting navigational puzzles, but their decisions to make the character slow in movement and the trial and error methods needed to solve the later puzzles ultimately lets down on the concept. By no means does this make it a poor game, quite the contrary; the earlier puzzles are truly gratifying, and while they do grow on some interesting concepts, the shortness of the games keeps it welcoming, so that the final few puzzles barely detract. A fictional story is also told describing the relationship between Escher and Sir Isaac Newton, and adds another layer to the game that makes progression all the more enjoyable. The mirrored levels provided after the base game is completed, as well as numerous little challenges and hidden secrets keep the game very replayable, but only if you actively look for them. Otherwise, it is a charmingly brief experience that will most likely leave you with a feeling of both satisfaction and desire for a little bit more.Providing that you have the patience to wade through its more irritating puzzles, you will find a great little game, and a wonderful hommage to the legendary artist.

Posted: January 29, 2015
												If you have ever looked at one of M.C. Escher's drawings of impossible buildings (with people walking on what should be a floor but you can't tell if it's actually the wall or the ceiling) and wondered what it would be like to wander around on that fantastical mind-bending playground, you need to play this game.Imagine FEZ, but with a hand-sketched style and set inside an M.C. Escher drawing.  The mental challenge reminds me of trying to solve one of those puzzles where you have to remove the metal ring from a rope threaded through a couple blocks of wood, or try to separate different-shaped metal rings from each other.  This game provides the same sort of spatial puzzle-solving challenge.The puzzles felt fair: nothing is hidden from you.  They do a great job with the difficulty curve: every level felt like it was just a little bit harder than the last one, and I didn't experience any big difficulty spikes.  That being said, once it gets going, this game does get quite difficult.  But if you stick with it and keep trying different things, you will keep making progress.  And every time you finish a tough level, the feeling of satisfaction and accomplishment is fantastic.If you are looking for a tough but fair puzzle game, I highly recommend that you check out The Bridge.

Posted: July 10, 2014
												This game had me within the first 10 seconds. It is beautifully drawn and boasts a unique style of gameplay. A definite must for Escher fans. The nature of the puzzles takes some time to get used to and the first half of the game isn't too difficult. In saying that, I spent a good deal of my hours played on the last half of the game, when the puzzles proved a lot more difficult. This game is a workout for the brain. Not much going on control wise.... walk left, walk right, tilt left, tilt right. It's just when to do what and how much of it to do that really matters in this game. Too much tilt and you can find yourself falling straight off the map. I found this game challenging enough. Each puzzle could be solved within a reasonable amount of time and it did not make me want to throw my computer out the window....which is always a good thing. Combine the puzzles with the artwork and gameplay and you have yourself a very enjoyable game. I recommend it to anyone who likes puzzle games and give it a 9 out of 10. Points lost because it just ended all too quickly for me. I wanted more!!!

Posted: July 21, 2014
												Let me start by saying although I recommend this game, I would rate it as a 6/10.It's a pretty good puzzler, and fans of games like Echochrome and Monument Valley will definitely be into it, as that's what I thought the game would be like when I bought it. Some are comparing it to Braid, but the only part that's the same is that you need to rewind time when you die.The reason for the low rating is because the puzzles are way too easy. Unless you're brand new to puzzle games, you'll breeze through the first half. Once you get to the mirrored versions, the difficulty does ramp up quite a lot, but even those require nothing but trial and error to finish them. "This didn't work, so let me try this... Nope, that didn't work, either, what about... Ah, yep. Got it." There was very little mental stimulation going on. Nothing I had to "figure out."If this game is on sale, it's worth picking up. If I had paid the full amount, my rating may have been lower.

												This is a very cool Indie Puzzler that has a style similar to that of M.C. Esher's drawings. Posted: June 5, 2015
												This is very slow-moving puzzler for the thinking man who likes to take a long look at the situation and envision the path to success. The gameplay consists of < > to rotate the world, and A D to move the character left and right (later on, W S to "invert" the world at specific points). Again, it's very slow. If you don't enjoy studying the puzzle and working out the correct path in your mind, there's not much else to keep you engaged. After a couple hours, I was really tired of feeling like I was walking through mud as I stared at more black and grey. It's kind of cool, but I certainly wouldn't buy it at full price. I think I just prefer puzzle games with a bit more pace and gameplay. If you enjoy the challenge of trying to envision something more than the act of doing it, this might be the type of puzzler you'll like. It's just not for me.

Posted: January 31, 2015
												If you're looking for a game to engross you for hours on end, let me start by saying this is not for you. With 8.5 hours into the game, I have all but completed the whole thing. The whole story was completed within probably 6 hours, if you would consider it a story. It's more of just multiple puzzles put together to really twist your brain. With each puzzle being completed, the story get just a little bit more "interesting".The game does make you think; afterall it is a puzzler. You simply have to walk left and right or rotate the world left or right. With just those four directional queues, you have to maneuver your way through around 50 puzzles. If you make a mistake, you can rewind time as far back as you want or need to. It feel like an indepth platformer / puzzler. The visual appeal is there in a sense. The game doesn't project visually stunning graphics. It's meant to have a simple, trippy, and hand drawn / rustic feeling. It gits the mysterious category it is portraying. The layout of the puzzles is what causes the trippy atmosphere. All of the puzzles encompass physically impossible maps and puzzle boards. Sometimes while rotating the world and walking, my eyes would flutter and become dizzy just from trying to comprehend how what I am doing is working. I don't play many games. I tend to look at them, think I'd enjoy them and add them to my library. This one actually caught my attention in my library and ended up binge playing it thoroughly. Is it worth the $9.99? I don't think so. If you can get it for a dollar or two, maybe. There was also a flaw in the game where, if you free fall for a long period of time, the framerate drops immensly to 1 or 2 fps. Very unhappy about that. This is the exact reason I did not get 100% of the achievements. The game also supports full controller support. I opted to use the keyboard only as 1) I didn't even realize that it supported the controller until I was 3/4 done this review and 2) I wanted to try just keyboard control. I use a controller 9/10 when playing a game through Steam or on my PC and wanted to really get a feel for the KB/M controls of games.Overall, I'm happy I played the game. It was interesting and something a little off the beaten path, per se. Would I ever play it again? I don't think so. Maybe once or twice to show people or try to get 100% one last time, but that's about it. I definitely won't be back anytime soon as I doubt the framerate issue will be fixed anytime soon.

Posted: September 6, 2014
												The Bridge will bend your brain. Not as much as say Antichamber, but it will force you to think ahead with how your manipulations affect the world around you.You play as an unnamed intellectual (who bears a striking resemblance to surrealist M. C. Escher) who starts out napping under an apple tree. After discovering your ability to rotate the world, you get him awake and discover a number of puzzle doors have appeared in his house; why and how they are here is hinted at in text descriptions given by the protagonist but nothing is really explained. A sense of dread accompanies the game's progress. The first time you meet 'the menace' (balls with huge grinning faces that kill you with one touch), there is an uneasy feeling that something is wrong with these places beyond their defiance of reality. The art is pretty in black and white; the story that is there serves as a vehicle to put you through the puzzles. There is a sense of achievement to be had with the later ones when momentum and quick thinking rotations come into play. One mechanic that could have been explained better is "the Veil", which is a curtain that lets you manipulate the gravitational pull on certain objects. At first I thought it let me rotate objects independent of myself, but eventually deciphered its effects. I blundered through the veil puzzles a good bit before its potential hit me.I got this for a dollar and found it easily worth that amount. Depending on your love of puzzle games, it is a good game to lose yourself in while trying to manipulate how to get the protagonist to his exit door. The downside is there is little to no replay. Some achievements help pad out the length as well as hidden collectibles, but basically the 48 puzzles behind the doors are it. The first half of the game is easy as it introduces concepts for you to play with, but then in the second half things get pretty tricky. The Bridge would make Escher proud. Not a game you buy for the story but for the experience of solving its strange puzzles and experiencing its strange, ruined landscapes.

Posted: June 19, 2014
												A frustrating, mind-bending puzzle game with a well-executed physics gimmick wrapped up in a quaint atmosphere. The pace at which new concepts are introduced scales very well with the level difficulty and prevents the puzzles from ever getting stale.

Posted: January 29, 2015
												The game uses a mechanic similar to And Yet It Moves, you twist the world around you to complete puzzles. Difficulty increases steadily, sometimes a little sharper than expected. The world gives you small environmental clues to help foster a solution.The only thing I will say is that the mirrored worlds are horse♥♥♥♥♥♥ They aren't mirrored, they are just more difficult versions of previous puzzles, often times needing a ridiculous amount of patience or finesse to pull off. Using physics that were never necessary before. It is no longer about solving the puzzle, all about abusing the game mechanic to get to your goal. It's the terrible half of the game.

Posted: January 29, 2015
												If you have ever looked at one of M.C. Escher's drawings of impossible buildings (with people walking on what should be a floor but you can't tell if it's actually the wall or the ceiling) and wondered what it would be like to wander around on that fantastical mind-bending playground, you need to play this game.Imagine FEZ, but with a hand-sketched style and set inside an M.C. Escher drawing.  The mental challenge reminds me of trying to solve one of those puzzles where you have to remove the metal ring from a rope threaded through a couple blocks of wood, or try to separate different-shaped metal rings from each other.  This game provides the same sort of spatial puzzle-solving challenge.The puzzles felt fair: nothing is hidden from you.  They do a great job with the difficulty curve: every level felt like it was just a little bit harder than the last one, and I didn't experience any big difficulty spikes.  That being said, once it gets going, this game does get quite difficult.  But if you stick with it and keep trying different things, you will keep making progress.  And every time you finish a tough level, the feeling of satisfaction and accomplishment is fantastic.If you are looking for a tough but fair puzzle game, I highly recommend that you check out The Bridge.
