Posted: January 31, 2015
												If you're looking for a game to engross you for hours on end, let me start by saying this is not for you. With 8.5 hours into the game, I have all but completed the whole thing. The whole story was completed within probably 6 hours, if you would consider it a story. It's more of just multiple puzzles put together to really twist your brain. With each puzzle being completed, the story get just a little bit more "interesting".The game does make you think; afterall it is a puzzler. You simply have to walk left and right or rotate the world left or right. With just those four directional queues, you have to maneuver your way through around 50 puzzles. If you make a mistake, you can rewind time as far back as you want or need to. It feel like an indepth platformer / puzzler. The visual appeal is there in a sense. The game doesn't project visually stunning graphics. It's meant to have a simple, trippy, and hand drawn / rustic feeling. It gits the mysterious category it is portraying. The layout of the puzzles is what causes the trippy atmosphere. All of the puzzles encompass physically impossible maps and puzzle boards. Sometimes while rotating the world and walking, my eyes would flutter and become dizzy just from trying to comprehend how what I am doing is working. I don't play many games. I tend to look at them, think I'd enjoy them and add them to my library. This one actually caught my attention in my library and ended up binge playing it thoroughly. Is it worth the $9.99? I don't think so. If you can get it for a dollar or two, maybe. There was also a flaw in the game where, if you free fall for a long period of time, the framerate drops immensly to 1 or 2 fps. Very unhappy about that. This is the exact reason I did not get 100% of the achievements. The game also supports full controller support. I opted to use the keyboard only as 1) I didn't even realize that it supported the controller until I was 3/4 done this review and 2) I wanted to try just keyboard control. I use a controller 9/10 when playing a game through Steam or on my PC and wanted to really get a feel for the KB/M controls of games.Overall, I'm happy I played the game. It was interesting and something a little off the beaten path, per se. Would I ever play it again? I don't think so. Maybe once or twice to show people or try to get 100% one last time, but that's about it. I definitely won't be back anytime soon as I doubt the framerate issue will be fixed anytime soon.

Posted: August 26, 2014
												Score: 7/10If you want a long, fullfilling challenge I'll warn you: The Bridge is a relatively short puzzle game, unless you get stuck in a single place for long you should really be able to finish EVERYTHING in about five hours (Though you should find yourself a guide if you want the collector achievement, some are impossible to get without hints that, no, you won't find in game).About the game in itself: the graphics are quite nice and lovely, if you love Escher you'll LOVE the game just by staring at its impossible graphics which, at the same time, make for mind-boggling puzzles.Sadly, the mechanics of the game are NOT as complex as the graphics suggests...As most puzzles games, expecially those where you control the world as well as your character, your abilities are limited (This time more by speed than actual limiting, but if a death-ball is between you and where you want to go forget about changing the world fast enough that you "skip" the ball: it'll follow you to your death)This however makes the solution maybe too linear, sometimes making the user start to meta-think the solution (going left not because it'll lead me to the solution but because going right will kill me so it's obviously not the answer).Adding more mechanics doesn't fix it, as essentially starts becoming "Okay, can't go left, nor right, I'll use that switcher there then."The hardest levels try to fix this by relying more on momentum and timed movements, while they succeed I personally dislike those due to feeling "un-puzzle-like" to me.The puzzles tend to be still challenging if you try to "understand" the solution, expecially due to the peculiar graphics making it hard to get a clear idea of what's going on the screen, so I suggest everyone playing this game to do this, but it lost some points due to being too weak to the "trial-and-error" solution.

Posted: May 22, 2014
												I played more of The Bridge today (I'd started it the other day, but playing it was making me sleepy). It's a puzzle platformer with simple controls: you can move your avatar left and right, and rotate the entire level clockwise and counterclockwise—and that's it, but it gets a lot of milage out of those simple controls, with increasingly difficult puzzles that require you to understand the game's mechanics to make it to the end of each level.After 24 levels, I thought I'd reached the end, but it turns out that this was just the halfway point, after which you're required to return to a harder version of each of the previous levels. Maybe I would have kept playing if the controls didn't feel so sluggish, or if the music hadn't become so very tedious, but at this point I've had my fill. Still, it's a decent game and I'd reccomend it, but it wasn't a revelatory experience on the level of Braid or FEZ.

Posted: November 10, 2013
												The Bridge is an abstract puzzle game, in both design and art style. The game itself has you controlling perspective and gravity to solve puzzles that play out in 360 degrees on the 2D plane, and the landscapes are modeled from the mathematical artworks of M.C. Escher. Given that the landscapes are made using real works of art, and his thick hand drawn style is applied to the game, it should come as no surprise that The Bridge is as good looking as it is. Aside from the puzzles and the style though, this game doesn't have much going for it. There seems to be something of a narrative trying to come out, but it is unintelligible and barely fleshed out enough to be too important. The game is interesting enough to warrant a look, but if you want a beautiful hand drawn 2D puzzler, buy Braid instead.

Posted: November 1, 2014
												TL;DR - A beautiful puzzle game revolving around a simple mechanic, with lots of content. A must-have for puzzle game connoisseurs.A great puzzle game with a simple but interesting mechanic. The art style looks absolutely amazing, and the puzzles themselves are well-designed. The impossible architectures that are in the levels are intriguing. It reminded me a bit of Braid, mostly because of the art style, but The Bridge's main mechanic, the rotation is original, as far as I know. There is also a time-rewinding mechanic in the game, so you can undo your mistakes if yu happen to mess up, which is a nice addition, since you don't have to restart the entire level in case you fail. There are many levels to play and collectibles to find, and after your first playthrough an alternative world is unlocked, in which you can play through more difficult versions of the original levels. I only had problems with 1-2 levels, the others can be figured out easily, or with a bit of thinking and planning.To sum this review up, The Bridge is a very ambitious puzzle game with puzzles revolving around a simple mechanic, and with an amazing art style. I'd highly recommend it.Edit: paraghraps

Posted: November 8, 2014
												A very nice game for puzzle-enthousiasts out there. It certainly thrives in originality with it's escheresque rules of geometry. Gameplay-mechanics are limited to a few dynamics that all revolve around the change or mere direction of gravitational forces. If i were to name a con, it would be that a lot of levels are solvable without really understanding the problem it sets out for the player. You basically just fumble your way to its solution. It wasn't untill the later levels, that the factor luck is minimised and you really have to wrap your head around the screwed up little universe that is the The Bridge. The game is at its best during those stages. When i finished the game in its entirety without resorting to any kind of walkthroughs i couldn't help but cheer for besting it. Yet i felt a kind of regret that as a result i am forced to leave its universe. You know you're playing a great game when you end up feeling like that.8/10

Posted: October 31, 2014
												Surprisingly dark puzzler.The levels in the game are split into 2 sets. First, you play through all the levels, then you play the "mirrored" levels which have extra things added to them which makes the puzzles much harder. It's a cool concept and gives the game some length by bringing the total number of levels ~40-50. In the puzzles, you can control which way the world is tilting and which direction your character walks in. By doing this, you have to get your character through a door which is the exit. All the levels follow an MC Escher type theme with impossible structures everywhere. Trying to wrap your head around the fact that the levels arent flat is one of the hardest things in the entire game. The levels starts out simple enough but then you move on to adding death balls, inversions to different colors, and veils which allow you to control the balls. The additional feature is the space bar which reverses time (Braid style) so you can fine tune your movements.The levels have a natural challenge to them as more levels get introduced. However, the last level in the main campaign has a ridiculous difficulty spike and the last two levels of the mirrored levels are insanely complex. The difficulty jumps but for someone who is really into puzzlers, you will love it. It's only 2-3 hours with me being terrible but it’s a good length for a puzzlerThere isn’t much of a story. You meet a dude and he goes through the doors. But if you read the plaques at the end of each set of rooms, you will get a sense of a scientist exploring a hypercube sort of deal (which is the mirrored). It's quite dark as each time you die, you get a message which depresses you. The music is creepy and adds to the atmosphere quite well. At the end of both the normal and mirrored edge, you try and cross a bridge... and stuff happens. I'm not sure what. But something happens. Overall, there is a story but I can’t make sense of it. However, it creates a wonderfully creepy atmosphereOverall, if you like difficult puzzlers, have fun. Otherwise, it’s not really worth your time for 10 dollars.

Posted: August 13, 2013
												Originality: 10/10 - Brilliant puzzle game that plays with surfaces, gravity, and mathematics in a way that I have never seen before. Not comparable to Antichamber.Gameplay: 9/10 - Clever use of grinning balls of doom, spaghettifying not-black holes, keys, sliding doors, and plain old gravity make this puzzle-by-puzzle game appealing. It could do with a little more explanation, though. The puzzles are deceptively simple in most cases, but nonetheless require a significant amount of brainpower. Don't expect to simply sit down and beat the game; breaks are mandatory.Story: 7/10 - You get doses of story at the end of each chapter, but there seems to be no way to go back and view them again, making it very difficult to piece the whole shebang together into some notion of what is going on.Interface and Graphics: 9/10 - The Bridge utilizes its own unique style of graphics, where black-and-white figures are drawn before you at the start of each level. The animations show stray pencil marks flashing in and out of existence around the characters, as if they are constantly being redrawn at 60 DPS (draws per second). The interface, and all text, all appears charmingly hand-drawn.Overall: 8.75/10 - Worth a buy, especially if you get it on sale. Not for the faint of mind. Breaks are highly recommended.

The following puzzle stumps me yet.I would have appreciated a gentler difficulty slope on the road to bogglement, but it is what it is (a very clever and attractive game), I am what I am (a rather unclever and unattractive gamer), and I cannot really blame the game for the latter circumstance.4 of 5 stars

Posted: December 26, 2015
												A beautifully crafted game in which you solve maze-like puzzles mostly by turning your world round and round and upside down. As you do so, sliding things slide, rolling things roll, and your character falls from floor to ceiling to wall.Sadly, if your mind is boggle-prone, you will soon encounter seemingly unsolvable puzzles. Boggled being my mind's normal resting state, I soon encountered a puzzle (the 3rd, if memory serves) that I had to revisit many times before the mind-bogglingly simple solution presented itself. The following puzzle stumps me yet.I would have appreciated a gentler difficulty slope on the road to bogglement, but it is what it is (a very clever and attractive game), I am what I am (a rather unclever and unattractive gamer), and I cannot really blame the game for the latter circumstance.4 of 5 stars

Posted: December 26, 2013
												In the best way to put it, The Bridge is good. It's not a legendary puzzler, nor is it anything to brush aside. The Bridge has wonderful artwork, charming music, and a interesting story. But the level designs fall through after time. They become less of a challenge to solve and more of an art piece to admire and turn. Gameplay is also rather short. It might take you maybe one to two hours to complete the first world before unlocking the dark version of the game, which is about the same length. It's a very short game with not much to enjoy after. But once you start playing it, it's a delight. I do recommend this. Price is very fair, and when it's on sale it's a steal.

Posted: December 26, 2013
												The Bridge is a puzzle platformer heavily inspired by M.C. Escher's works. It's main feature is its crazy impossible space and really cool space manipulation mechanics. It also features some time-manipulation mechanic that reminds me of Braid - You can rewind time if you make mistakes, so there isn't really a "game-over" state.For the most part, solving a level is just a matter of figuring out how to navigate the weird space you find yourself in. That is not an easy feat since you can easily get disoriented by the impossible geometry. In a few levels timing your moves plays significant role too.There are 4 worlds with about 6 levels each. In each world a new gameplay mechanic is added making the game more complex the further you progress. After you complete the game, you can revisit each level in a 'mirrored' mode which features new and more difficult puzzles.Depending on your ability and on how much time you spend looking for hidden items and completing achievements, the game can probably take anywhere between 4 to 10 hours. It took me about 7; although I did use a guide to find in what levels each of the hidden items are located, I did take me a while to finish some of the harder levels.So, if you like puzzle platformers and enjoy M.C. Escher's works, you'll definitely like this game!

Posted: November 27, 2016
												The Bridge is an amazing and original puzzle game. It's easy to play, intellectually challenging, visually appealing and has no flaws in terms of style and game design. There you’ll encounter various fascinating puzzles in tricky labyrinths.  Some of them will be quite easy, others might test your patience and even drive you crazy with perplexity, so the game definitely provides you with a decent thought-provoking time.However, it is also relatively short and you can get a slight feeling of vapidity due to the lack of story. Yet its gloomy atmosphere and unique art style absolutely make up for it.All in all, it’s an enjoyable experience that encourages you to think differently and a great treat for puzzle game fans.9/10.

Posted: May 28, 2014
												If you like the Penrose stairs illusion in the lithograph print Relativity of M.C. Escher you will love this game. It is simple to understand how the mechanic of the game work and the chapter progression always add something new as you progress. The music is very soothing and add to the whole enigma feeling of the game.  The sound effects adds tension and a sense of urgency... especially when you hear the sound of those rolling troll heads. The game mechanic allow you to rewind your actions pretty much like in Braid so mistakes are easily fixed unlike the puzzles themselves which add a lot of reward and felicity when you actually succeed.Of course you will get stuck more than once and you will have to figure out how this virtual rubix cube works to make it to the end.8/10

Posted: January 7
												I will review all my humble bundle games and see which is worth playing and which is not! Like a lot of people i buy H.B. games as a pack because i want some of the games, but not all. I will play for 5 minutes (or a litlle bit more) and give you my opinion on it. Sometimes the game will surprise me, sometimes it will be a total dissapointment. Just keep in mind this is my opinion only and is not an objective view of the game. You might actually like it!The review will be constructed into 5 parts:1. Game description (from what i've seen in the time i've played).2. Did i finish the game (YES/NO/Maybe in the future) and why.3. Pros/Cons.4. Final thoughts.5. RatingSo let's beggin...1. Game description:Puzzle game with an interesting twist. You control the world around you and the character. Your goal is to enter a door. Sounds like the most simple thing ever right? You are wrong. So wrong. The game ramps up the difficulty quite fast and it varies so much from level to level. I find that some puzzles take 1-2 minutes while on others I spent 10 times as much. The only problem is the difficulty in some levels  is not from the puzzle part of the level but from the hazards that kill you. You have to act fast to avoid them. Visually it’s nothing much. I would have liked a few more colors but I guess that was the idea, to look like a sketch. There is a small story and it is a little philosophical. I kinda enjoyed it.2. Did i finish the game? In the processI still have the game installed and I will finish it one day. The fact that sometimes I have to replay the level several times due to me being killed by the hazards is annoying. However I never felt like I was cheated by the game. I actually deserved that death because I didn’t  go the way the puzzle wanted me to3. Pros/Cons.PROS:- Interesting mechanic- Nicely designed levels- Interesting storyCONS:- Bland visuals- Annoying traps4. Final thoughts:I like this game despite the downsides mentioned earlier. If you like puzzle games get it. It’s nothing that will blow you away but it’s a nice game to sit back and relax playing a few levels between bigger games. 5. Rating7/10

Posted: January 3
												For me it's always nice to find a game that I at least would call a piece of art and in short this game succeeds in what is necessary imo: Adding interaction to the sum of all parts and after all being more than the sum of all parts. I say that as someone that is not particularly fond of puzzle games.Note that I have not played through the mirrored chapters yet, I guess there are no new pictures in the mirrored chapters but the puzzles will be more difficult, that's ok but I will take my time for this. Even without the mirrored chapters the game definitly is worth much more than the 2,- € I paid for it imo. Well, if you primarly are after solving as many puzzles per time unit as possible than this may not be for you, the game is not too short in my eyes though.The puzzles in the beginning are easy, additional puzzle elements are added on the way but the game does not get too difficult. Well, there was one puzzle that I solved without knowing why it did not work in the previous attempt and I got stuck a few times, especially in the last level of chapter IV, however this could also be related to an illness that makes concentrating harder for me, I also got stuck once in a level that I regard as easy after seeing the solution.The interaction is simple, you can walk around and also turn the picture which effectivly means you change the direction of gravity, you can also use an inverter if present in the picture but I leave it to you to find out what that means exactly. Together with all the other puzzle elements the resulting complexity of the whole game is fine imo.The music and sound effects are good too, at some point the music changed to be rather threatening which was a small irritation for me but overall it's not distracting.The puzzles get a 9/10 from me but I will not disregard the whole experience with a number, well, maybe the number pi if I had to choose.

Posted: April 16
												The game have nice look to it. I can’t say much about the sound since I mostly played it muted. The story is a very small portion of the game and was for me uninteresting, even though I liked how they moved it forward through small portions of a journal. For more important things like the gameplay and puzzles I have more to say. The puzzles are good and the level of challenge increase mostly in a constant direction upwards. You spin the level (change the direction of the gravitational pull) to move you or obstacles. At some levels you can even change how the pull is for individual objects. This is cool and different. You can also change your character to a inverted version which has the opposite gravity pull the the normal. I do have some bones to pick with this game however. - A lot of the puzzles are more about timing rather than figure the puzzle out. - The do not use the visual illusions of the artworks close to enough. Mostly it’s just in the back/foreground rather than a part of the gameplay.- Half of the game is the same levels repeated but in a “hard-mode” called “mirrored world”. The levels here are harder and plays slightly different, but why not different level design with new artwork? They also tease you twice with having colour to the game. This should definitely be done for the whole mirrored world if you ask me.- The simplicity of the game makes most levels beatable just by spinning back and forth a bit to see what happens. This is not a big downside at all but it did take away some brainwork.- Even though I did get stuck sometimes (but only when I played it late at night balls deep in wishes for sleep) the game never made me feel smart for beating it. I do believe that if they gave you more freedom like letting you change to your inverted self whenever wherever, instead at specific spots on specific levels, it would be harder to know when and where to use it. However, a lot of levels wouldn’t work if that was the case. For words to end this miserable excuse of a review I would like to recommend it to puzzle fans. This is a different puzzler than most and worth the playthrough for the genres fans. If you’re not that kind of fan I would direct you to start with a more humorous puzzler like “day of the tentacle”.

Posted: March 5
												A nice callback to the early aughts, when everyone and their dog was putting out puzzle platformers made in flash, but with some new polish. The control scheme gives it a uniqueness that is so very, very rare in platformers, and while it does make the perennial pecadillo of a 'shadow dimension' mechanic -- the plain oatmeal of puzzle platformers that everyone recognizes and was played out back in the early aughts -- but combined with the gravity mechanics, it actually becomes interesting. The game even introduced a mechanic that I literally had not seen before in this sort of game.So yeah. It takes a while to get interesting, and 24 levels is pretty damn short, but it's definitely worth checking out.
